fields.description: On my team we have settled on naming our branches feature/JIRA-ID-Short-Description. Unfortunately, if you never mention the JIRA issue in a commit comment, it will never be noticed by the stash pull request. I'd like the pull request to detect if I've used a JIRA issue in the branch name and automatically link to the JIRA issue that way.
fields.summary: Pull Request Should Detect JIRA Issues in Branch Name

fields.description:
- Upgraded to 2.11.4 to fix the scrolling "jump" issue in Firefox.  Looks fixed for up-and-down scrolling, but when scrolling side-to-side (eg for long code lines) the whole page jumps upward to hide the header information.

- When using atrackpad on OSX in Chrome or Safari, the scrolling also jumps around.
fields.summary: Diff scrolling glitches

fields.description: This should be probably 5 min fix ;). On attached screenshot it would be nice to see actual sixth reviewer instead of "1" icon. Showing the more icon with one entry is a bit silly.
fields.summary: Stash should show the "more reviewers" icon only if there are at least 2 reviewers that doesn't fit in limit

fields.description:
Right now the Stash notifications are very chatty: everyone on the PR gets an email for every comment and every new commit.  The former is fine (although batching in STASH-2839 would be an improvement) but the latter are almost always just noise.  For example:

- Author submits PR and tags two reviewers.
- Reviewers provide substantive feedback that requires the author to refactor a large part of the PR.
- Author goes through the process of commiting the new changes, iterating and pushing each commit as she goes (or as she tries to get the build to go green, for example).  

Each of the additional commits sends an email to the reviewers, even though the PR may not be ready for re-review.  Ideally, the reviewer should comment "Updated, please take a look" when the PR is ready for re-review, which would make the intermediate commit emails just noise.

I'd like to either kill these notifications globally or allow users to opt-out of them.
fields.summary: Allow opt-out of specific email notification types

fields.description: Currently fork syncing stops working if someone does a force push to the original repo. It seems very reasonable for fork syncing to stop working if that happens. However, the users who are depending on fork syncing should be notified via email  and the inbuilt message box that it has stopped. It should not silently stop working.
fields.summary: Fork sync should notify when it stops syncing

fields.description:
From a developer: "I merged a pull request and a few seconds later pushed another commit onto that branch - that commit ended up merged too! Weird."

Maybe the merge request doesn't include the SHA being merged?
fields.summary: Merging from web UI can include extra commits

fields.description:
I have worked on a branch and cleaned up my commits with interactive rebase (switched order of one commit). I then created a pull request but forgot to push my changes so I then force-pushed everything after the pull request was already open.

Under the commit tab commits are displayed correctly but in the activity tab it seems that the commits are ordered by date. Maybe this is related to STASH-3560.
fields.summary: Commit order in pull request activity does not match commit tab

fields.description:
1. View a pull request.
2. Click on a commit to view the changed files.
3. Look (in vain?) for a way to get back to the original PR.
fields.summary: I can't seem to easily jump back into the PR from the commits themselves via the Stash UI

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update – December 2017|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Bitbucket Server team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-bug-fixing-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication. If you're really passionate about this suggestion, please comment with your case in detail and we'll reconsider. Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Imran Khan
Product Manager - Bitbucket Server and Data Center
{panel}

I think I can speak for many of us when I say that it would be very beneficial to have a People directory / tab on the main taskbar of Stash, just like the one Confluence has (seen here - https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Searching+the+People+Directory)

A feature like this would allow project & system administrators to get a much better overview of:

1. who is doing what.
2. allow fellow team members to find out who else is working on a project & the amount of commits / activity they have done on said projects.
3. who has contributed to most in the last week / month.
4. etc.
fields.summary: Peoples Directory / Tab similar to Confluence

fields.description: When viewing activities of a pull request, all activities (inline code comments, general comments and commits updates) are shown on activities tab in chronological order. In Stash 2.11.3, there is no way to filter the activities according to user's interests. It would be more convenient for users to set what kind of activities to view. For example, pull request approvers may be interested in inline code comments and general comments only during approval. Managers may check the general comments only.
fields.summary: As a user, I would like to have the activities of a pull request grouped by different categories so that I can browser the information more easily

fields.description:
When a large diff/PR is scrolled to the bottom, the view resets with the lower content unavailable.

I am attaching a video that shows the problem, I only scroll the page down using a two-finger swipe, and the page keeps resetting once I reach the bottom.
fields.summary: Diff view scrolling gets reset and some content becomes invisible

fields.description: Here is the question \ issue. https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/272966/is-there-a-way-to-delete-system-ssh-keys-in-stash-for-user-who-has-left-the-company#
fields.summary: how to remove a system ssh key for a user who has left a company

fields.description:
Problem:
When we go to the permissions page of an Stash project (/projects/<PROJECTKEY>/permissions) with https, the default gravatar will be loaded from a http instead of https. This will result in an security error (see attachment). It seems that the issue only occurs at the permissions screens. In other screens the default avatar uses https.

Suggested solution:
I would prefer that the scheme (http or https) for external url's will be based on the scheme which is configured in the Base url on the Server settings page of stash.
fields.summary: Default avatar is loaded via http instead of https when using a reverse proxy
Allow "rest/api/1.0/admin/groups/more-members" for licensed_user

fields.description:
"Performing backup" or "Performing maintenance" messages only show to users coming either at the very beginning or at the very end of the backup process. Any other users will just see an unresponsive Stash.

Users lucky enough to get the "Performing backup" screen with the progress bar don't see any progress at all until the backup is finally finished.

This is a major issue for us because it makes unfeasible to backup Stash during work times and reduces the window to 1 backup a day, during the night.
fields.summary: Stash appears stuck for most of the time during a backup with stash-backup-client

fields.description: Enterprise environments may require to separate Oracle schema owner from the connecting user. Such scenario will currently fail on upgrades and plugin installations at very least, but the setup needs to be tested until we can support it even with remarks.
fields.summary: Support Oracle usage of different schema without DDL permissions

fields.description: It's very common to have PR comments vanish from the "Diff" view when new revisions of a commented file are committed. The comments still appear in the "Overview" view, but this behavior makes it much more difficult to verify that identified issues have been addressed in the commented file.
fields.summary: Pull request comments vanish from the "Diff" view as new revisions are committed

fields.description:
When commenting on Java code, I'd like an easy way to include snippets of Java code. Unfortunately, Java generic class specifiers get interpreted as HTML tags which have no visible presence in the comment. Also, it's a hassle to include formatted (intented) code in a PR comment, because I end up having to hand-encode non-breaking space characters to maintain the indention.

I'd like to have the ability to paste code snippets into a PR comment and have the generic class specifiers and indention retained automatically.
fields.summary: Add the ability to include Java generics and code formatting in pull request comments

fields.description:
EXPECT: When I create a pull request comment, I expect this comment to remain anchored to the content to which the comment relates.
ACTUAL: If changes get merged into the "master" branch underneath the PR that cause the related content to move, the comment will no longer be attached to the original content. The anchoring appears to specify a fixed line number, instead of tracking with the original content from revision to revision.
fields.summary: Anchor pull request comments to content to which they relate, not to a fixed line number

fields.description:
MacOS decided to do away with scroll bars unless you're actively scrolling. Unfortunately, this makes left/right scrolling kind of painful (I've forced scroll bars to be on all the time myself, but it is annoying some other users).

The same issue happens to the left/right arrow (*not Mac OS specific* in this case) when the viewing a new file by using with "j" or "k". For example, when you switch to the next file to review with "j", then the left/right arrow keys stop working but the up and down arrow keys are fine. The focus needs to be set inside diff area so that the left and right arrow keys will work.
fields.summary: Allow using left/right arrow to move side by side diff left/right
Disable relative dates

fields.description: It would be nice to have a keyboard shortcut when looking at side by side diffs for jumping to the next change in the file (side by side seems to always show the whole file, so if you're looking at a large file with a change at the top and another at the bottom, it can be annoying).
fields.summary: Jump to next change in diff keyboard shortcut
Changing groupname casing in external user management causes intermittent loss of group membership

fields.description:
We would like to have a way to indicate that the contents of a pull request have changed significantly enough so that everyone who had approved a pull request will be unapproved and have to review the pull request again.  This would require there being a way for the creator of the pull request to have the ability to remove other peoples approvals.  

I realize there is a plugin to auto unapprove everyone on a new update, but often we make small changes before merging in a pull request, such as changing a database name in a config file.  When this happens, we don't want everyone to be unapproved.
fields.summary: Unapprove all pull request reviewers after major change

fields.summary: Unable to start Stash as git rev-list fails rescoping pull requests

fields.description:
When a coworker comments on a PR, I'm sent an email with the comment, the file the comment was in and the line the comment was on. That data is useful, but I find I almost always click the "View comment" button to give the comment more context. The context given on the web is great (the overview page does a perfect job of showing both the comment and surrounding code), but I'd prefer to have this context in my notification emails.

Providing context via a code snippet allows me to quickly scan and find the code in question. Having a code snippet to reference is especially useful when I'm modifying a branch while a coworker is giving me feedback, since the line number often doesn't match up with what I have locally after minor edits.
fields.summary: Inline code snippet in comment notification emails

fields.description:
Pages different:
https://www.atlassian.com/software/stash/download?v=1 (Stash 2.11.3)
https://www.atlassian.com/software/stash/download?v=2 (Stash 2.11.2 - previous)
fields.summary: Stash 2.11.3 not available in new download design

fields.description: Based on [this support issue|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/SSP-3700], I believe that adding a note to the official "Installing Stash on Windows" document about adding inbound connection rules to the firewall could save some customer pain while we don't implement this in a Windows installer.
fields.summary: Add to Stash documentation note on Windows firewall rules

fields.description:
The main way I interact with PR's is through the diff view.

This means that sometimes I miss out on reading global comments, because the only way to see them is through the `Overview` tab ... but the overview tab for me is mostly noise. It includes
- activity stream stuff like "hans approved this PR 3 days ago" which I don't care so much about (I do care that other people have approved it, but I see that from the icons in the top right)
- comments from the diff view, which I have already read because I prefer to read them in the context of the code; diff view is better for this

I really like the way Bitbucket displays global comments at the top of its diff view. This works really well for me; I have the diff view and the global comments right there.
fields.summary: I miss reading global comments sometimes (they're easy to skim over)

fields.description:
We have Stash connected to our company Active Directory for user management and there are only a few Stash users but many users in AD. When adding reviewers to a pull request, the selection includes all AD users. Could this be restricted to just stash users?

We have no control over the AD groups or structure.
fields.summary: Restrict pull request reviewer selection to stash users
Prevent Stash from starting with a database driver which is not JDBC 4 compliant

fields.description:
We sometimes have multiple reviewers on pull requests that leave many comments.

Since the "Overview" page contains context information for comments and is not loading everything at once. It is difficult to get an overview of all the comments, and if they have been addressed.

It would be nice with a list of comments, with just the first line of each comment. So it is easy to get an overview. Maybe even a feature to mark a comment as resolved.
fields.summary: Overview of comments to pull request

fields.description:
The use case I'm imagining is as follows:
My goal is to have 2 additional people look at my code before merging it.  I am accomplishing this by requiring 2 approvals in order to merge a PR.

1. I create a PR and add Joffrey and Tyrion as reviewers:
2. Tyrion raises an issue
3. Joffrey decides to implement the issue himself, and pushes changes to the branch to be merged
4. Tyrion approves the Pull Request
5. Joffrey approves the Pull Request and merges

In this case, only 2 sets of eyes were really reviewing the code (rather than 3, as intended).  I would like to configure this repo to require 3 approvals (2 independent and myself), to enforce that there are always at least 2 other people looking at the code, other than the originator - however I can't do this because Stash doesn't allow me to approve my own pull requests.  It would be nice to have this option available.
fields.summary: Allow Pull Request Owner to approve their own Pull Request

fields.description:
I'm using Firefox 27 on Ubuntu 12.04.

Steps to reproduce:
* Open any pull request in the 'Diff' tab, say https://stash.atlassian.com/projects/BIZPLAT/repos/intsys-utils/pull-requests/6/diff
* Note that the first visible line number is "1"
* Scroll down until the part of the header displaying the "Clone", "Fork", etc buttons has disappeared
* Note that the file has now jumped down over a hundred lines, in my case the first line is now "123". The "Merge", "Decline", "Edit" buttons are still visible and the diff view has not reached the top of the page yet.
fields.summary: Scrolling down in a PR skips about a page of text

fields.description:
Placing a fenced code block inside a list item does not work. The following sample:

{code}
## Installation

1. Require the package using composer:

   ~~~bash
   $ composer require vendor/package:1.*
   ~~~

2. Publish the module's assets:

   ~~~bash
   $ bin/console asset:publish
   ~~~
{code}

Should produce a list with two items each containing a fenced code block.

Instead the result is two separate lists and no code blocks (just raw text with literal ~~~bash in the output).
fields.summary: Markdown doesn't render fenced code block inside a list

fields.description:
It would be great to be able to see, at a glance, the Bamboo build status of *both* the Pull Request's source *and* destination.

It might be good to know that master is broken before merging to it and making the problem worse.
fields.summary: Show Build Status for Destination Brach in Pull Requests

fields.description: If you are managing users externally, the change password link doesn't work because Stash only reads from external directories. Changing passwords is only valid for internally managed users.
fields.summary: Can't access your account link should not be shown when external directories are active

fields.description:
Add customisation options to the Stash homepage

* Enable repositories to be _starred_
* Display starred repositories the homepage and drop down menu
* Display pull request activities and notifications on the homepage repository
fields.summary: Customisable Homepage

fields.description:
In Stash comments that use the triple backtick to create code blocks, XML is being flattened our to a single line.

Example of issue:
{code}
Some plain text...
```
<parent>
  <child>content</child>
</parent>
```
{code}
Is being rendered as...
{code}Some plain text...
<parent>  <child>content</child></parent>{code}

However, if you don't have the line of plaintext directly above the code block, it seems to render just fine.
fields.summary: Improve Markdown rendering to not require blank lines around code blocks

fields.description:
Right now we get default branch names when creating a branch from Jira like this:
feature/ISSUE-123-some-long-branch-title and would like to shorten them to something shorter.

Is that possible with some setting?
fields.summary: Ability to change the default length of branch names in Stash generated from a Jira issue.

fields.description:
'-' dashes are not valid as part of a JIRA project key however, there are work arounds https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/Project+Key+Patterns+with+invalid+characters.

When viewing the JIRA issue for stash for an issue key like BIG-PROJ-1, the JIRA dialog just shows a spinner. 

There is a javascript error because the regex to extract the JIRA base url from the issue url does not account for invalid characters like '-'
fields.summary: JIRA issues dialog: JIRA keys with banned characters do not show

fields.description:
[A bug in hibernate 4.3.0|https://hibernate.atlassian.net/browse/HHH-8811] shipped within Stash 2.11.2 could potentially cause two issues with both Oracle and MySQL databases.

These issues are now fixed on Stash 2.11.3, which ships with Hibernate 4.3.4.

fields.description:
The issue here is annoying, but easy to explain:

{noformat}
Caused by: org.w3c.dom.DOMException: INVALID_CHARACTER_ERR: An invalid or illegal XML character is specified. 
	at org.apache.xerces.dom.CoreDocumentImpl.createAttribute(Unknown Source) ~[xercesImpl-2.9.1.jar:na]
	at org.apache.xerces.dom.ElementImpl.setAttribute(Unknown Source) ~[xercesImpl-2.9.1.jar:na]
	at org.cyberneko.html.parsers.DOMFragmentParser.startElement(DOMFragmentParser.java:433) ~[nekohtml-1.9.7.jar:na]
	at org.cyberneko.html.HTMLTagBalancer.callStartElement(HTMLTagBalancer.java:1019) ~[nekohtml-1.9.7.jar:1.9.7]
	at org.cyberneko.html.HTMLTagBalancer.startElement(HTMLTagBalancer.java:652) ~[nekohtml-1.9.7.jar:1.9.7]
	at org.cyberneko.html.filters.DefaultFilter.startElement(DefaultFilter.java:136) ~[nekohtml-1.9.7.jar:na]
	at org.cyberneko.html.filters.NamespaceBinder.startElement(NamespaceBinder.java:278) ~[nekohtml-1.9.7.jar:na]
	at org.cyberneko.html.HTMLScanner$ContentScanner.scanStartElement(HTMLScanner.java:2680) ~[nekohtml-1.9.7.jar:1.9.7]
	at org.cyberneko.html.HTMLScanner$ContentScanner.scan(HTMLScanner.java:2012) ~[nekohtml-1.9.7.jar:1.9.7]
	at org.cyberneko.html.HTMLScanner.scanDocument(HTMLScanner.java:910) ~[nekohtml-1.9.7.jar:1.9.7]
	at org.cyberneko.html.HTMLConfiguration.parse(HTMLConfiguration.java:499) ~[nekohtml-1.9.7.jar:1.9.7]
	at org.cyberneko.html.HTMLConfiguration.parse(HTMLConfiguration.java:452) ~[nekohtml-1.9.7.jar:1.9.7]
	at org.cyberneko.html.parsers.DOMFragmentParser.parse(DOMFragmentParser.java:166) ~[nekohtml-1.9.7.jar:na]
	at org.owasp.validator.html.scan.AntiSamyDOMScanner.scan(AntiSamyDOMScanner.java:172) ~[na:na]
	... 340 common frames omitted
{noformat}

Those 4 pull requests have a bad markdown description or comment that our HTML sanitizer (to stop XSS attacks) is dying on. This has been fixed in [newer versions of Stash|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-3829]. For now, unless you want to upgrade, the easiest thing to do is to find the offending text and fix it directly in the database.

The general nature of the problem is that Stash chokes on a particular XML-like pattern of text in comments. From other customers with the same problem we believe the text is similar to the following "<SomeLettersOrNumbers " followed by a character that is invalid for an XML attribute. E.g. "<a -" or "<abc !" (note that the quotes I use are for punctuation in this paragraph - these quotes are not in the comment text in the database).

From this error {{2014-02-25 15:07:42,652 WARN  [http-bio-8443-exec-1531] a_svn 907x552466x5 1ydvh8d 10.30.130.141 "GET /projects/DSST/repos/ca/pull-requests/524/overview HTTP/1.1" c.atlassian.stash.json.JsonRenderer Failed to marshal com.atlassian.stash.internal.pull.InternalPullRequest to JSON}}, this will find all the comments that are probably suspect:

{code}
select c.id, c.comment_text from sta_comment c inner join sta_pr_comment_activity prca on c.id = prca.comment_id inner join sta_pr_activity a on a.activity_id = prca.activity_id inner join sta_pull_request pr on a.pr_id = pr.id inner join repository repo on pr.to_repository_id = repo.id inner join project proj on repo.project_id = proj.id
where pr.scoped_id =  and repo.slug='plugins' and proj.key='DSST'
{code}

And the pull request description:

{code}
select pr.description from sta_pull_request pr
inner join repository repo on pr.to_repository_id = repo.id 
inner join project proj on repo.project_id = proj.id 
where pr.scoped_id = 524 and repo.slug='plugins' and proj.name='DSST'
{code}

You just need to tweak the queries to use the different project name and PR scoped ids for each failing PR. When you have the results feel free to post them here, unless they match my description above and you feel confident about updating them directly. As always, before you make any direct changes to the database _please_ make sure you have backed it up appropriately.
fields.summary: 500 errors on PR page due to markdown renderer

fields.description:
* If I tick of a PR as approved, I don't want emails from future edits and comments unless I'm specifically mentioned
* I want the ability to mark a PR as "Don't merge this until it is fixed" without declining the PR. (ie, still get updated with changes)
* I'd like emails from Stash to be batched in some way, so 50 comments in 5 minutes would be fewer emails than 1 email per comment.
fields.summary: Here are things I wish stash did

fields.description: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/268252/how-do-i-get-stash-http-clone-url-now
fields.summary: Allow toggling of the authority part in clone URLs on RepositoryCloneLinksRequest

fields.description:
when creating a new repository people now get instructions based on ssh:// or https:// protocol based on the availability of ssh keys in their profile. 

It would be nice (just as is done on github) to have the user use the clone button to switch between https:// and ssh:// and have the page with instructions updated automatically.
fields.summary: have the clone button present on the new repository URL

fields.description:
Side by side diff is an awesome feature that people at our company have been wanting for a while now. 

However, there is a slight change that I'd like to have available as an option. Right now, the side-by-side diffs have a sort of "taper", where added and deleted lines on one side show up as a thin marker on the other, kind of like how the Meld diff viewer does it - this makes it so that the left and right sides *don't actually line up* a lot of the time. 

It would be nice to have an option to have a 'synchronized' diff, where the lines always line up, kind of like how Gerrit and vimdiff do it. I can attach examples if that would be helpful.
fields.summary: Line-synchronized side-by-side diffs

fields.description:
The addition of side-by-side diff view in Stash v2.11.2 is GREAT and our Dev team is very appreciative.   A number of our projects have some rather large source files and one request for improvement has been to have the side-by-side diff view show only the diffs plus some amount of expandable context.  I.e. similar to the expandable context in the "unified diff mode" except that the diffs are shown side-by-side rather than in-line.

I can see how this might be tricky to implement and so if it's not possible or able to put on the roadmap for some time, I think the feature request in STASH-4427 (add keyboard shortcuts/links to jump between diffs in side-by-side view) is a good start.
fields.summary: Enable showing only diff + context in Side by Side diff view

fields.description:
We have a large code base with several developers working on several modules.  To reduce the "noise" of the large amount of traffic, we rely heavily on forks to keep the work/conversations scoped.  Within our forks, when it is time to integrate a feature, we create a pull request to the fork master.  This acts as more of a code review than a pull request, as we have no intention of merging this PR.  Once the feature has been sufficiently reviewed, we decline the pull request and create a new one in the primary repository so the feature can be merged in to integration.  This keeps our primary repository's PR list an actual list of features awaiting merge, rather than a hodgepodge of complete features and open pull requests.  

It would be nice if we could simply change the destination repository in the pull request so the history of the code review can live in the same place as the merge history.
fields.summary: Change target repository for opened Pull Requests
Typo in developer docs

fields.description:
Error when merging: "New changes were pushed to <target-branch> in PROJECT/repo while the merge was being performed. Please retry the merge."

This can be the result of the event queue being full. 

This can be worked around by merging locally.

Merging should try to resolve the ref

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update – December 2017|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Bitbucket Server team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-bug-fixing-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication. If you're really passionate about this suggestion, please comment with your case in detail and we'll reconsider. Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Imran Khan
Product Manager - Bitbucket Server and Data Center
{panel}

The 'source' branch in the 'create pull request' screen could default to the last branch that the current user pushed a commit to. This is often likely to be the right one.
fields.summary: Default branch in 'create pull request' screen

fields.description:
We are working with Kelvin Yap; he asked us to submit the following via Jira.  

Before entering into an agreement with Atlassian for Stash Enterprise, a security audit was performed on our Stash instance.  One finding was that the server could potentially be exploited because it permits HTTP PUT and DELETE.  As we found, Stash relies on these for a number of internal operations, e.g. editing pull requests, deleting SSH keys, and deleting repositories.

For us to proceed with Stash, we need a way to ensure that any PUT/DELETE operation is authenticated and logged, else it is rejected.  We are already using the LDAP integration.

I will be out of the office next week, but we really need to resolve this issue during my absence.  Please use [REDACTED] as a focal point for assistance.
fields.summary: Require authenticated HTTP PUT and DELETE actions

fields.description:

For example once the local backup is completed the latest backup is uploaded to an S3 bucket with API keys provided via the backup-config.properties file.
fields.summary: S3 Bucket Upload for Offsite Backups

fields.description:
We need to configure backup-config.properties in order to be able to automate backups.

It would be nice to have a variable to limit the number of backups in the backup-config.properties file and for the Stash Backup Client to cleanup old backups.

So all I need to worry about is running the client via cron.
fields.summary: Limit Backups via Config

fields.description: I have a plugin that replies to a comment with a commit id if the commit message contains the comment ID in it.  For now, users need to hover over the comment and look at the status bar in order to know what the comment ID is.  It would be nice to have this number displayed on the comment somewhere, so that its more easily referenceable.
fields.summary: Display comment ID on each comment

fields.description: It would be very useful, to extend the markdown rendering with a regex search and replace. So, as a Stash Administrator I could configure the markdown engine to search and replace certain text strings with external links or custom HTML. Doing so would allow me to create links to external tools simply by finding certain text patterns in my Pull request descriptions, commit comments, etc. Ultimately, I'm more less concerned about the rendered markdown of file contents and more concerned about the rendering of meta-data (Pull request descriptions, comments , commits, etc). However having it apply to both would be useful. Please see "Section commentlink" - https://gerrit-documentation.storage.googleapis.com/Documentation/2.8.1/config-gerrit.html for a sample implementation of this concept. The configuration of such looks like the following: {noformat} [commentlink "bugzilla"] match = "(bug\\s+#?)(\\d+)" link = http://bugs.example.com/show_bug.cgi?id=$2 [commentlink "tracker"] match = ([Bb]ug:\\s+)(\\d+) html = $1$2 {noformat} basically it would look for the text 'bug #1234' and convert that to a link like: 'http://bugs.example.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1234' This is a feature common to most code browsing, and code review systems. And if included in Stash, would help set it far above any other competing product.
fields.summary: Extending markdown with configurable links

fields.description:
Cloning git repositories from Stash via SSH often fail with the following message:

Receiving objects:  17% (6092/34764), 37.64 MiB | 985.00 KiB/s   
Receiving objects:  17% (6092/34764), 38.63 MiB | 988.00 KiB/s   
Receiving objects:  17% (6092/34764), 39.63 MiB | 993.00 KiB/s   
Connection to <hostname_redacted> closed by remote host.
fatal: early EOF
fatal: The remote end hung up unexpectedly
fatal: index-pack failed

The point in the transfer at which this occurs isn't consistent, but if it fails it does so generally before 25% complete.

When we disable the SCM Cache plugin on Stash, the problem occurs much less frequently, but still does occur.  Desktop (tortoisegit) users have more success w/ the SCM Cache plugin disabled, but it still fails sometimes. {panel:title=Atlassian Update – December 2017|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Bitbucket Server team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-bug-fixing-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication. If you're really passionate about this suggestion, please comment with your case in detail and we'll reconsider. Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Imran Khan
Product Manager - Bitbucket Server and Data Center
{panel}

We're using Stash in an Enterprise environment where we have a number of different clients accessing for different projects.  At this point Stash doesn't provide a way for Admins to limit who can browse users.  Right now when you mention someone or try to add them to a pull request you see a full list of users and their email addresses.  This is a huge security risk and has effectively halted the our roll out of Stash until this issue can be resolved.

The ability to limit who can browse users exists in JIRA and has been invaluable for security.  We would like to see this same level of security applied to Stash.
fields.summary: Allow restriction of the Browse User Permission

fields.description:
When I write the commit message we add the sign-off part so most of our commits follow this pattern:
{code}
Do some stuff (message no longer than 50 chars)

Longer description that possibly has more than 1 line
containing explanation (optional, we add it just in case
the first line is not enough to understand what's
happening.

Signed-off-by: Igor Popov <igor.popov@napa.fi>
{code}

See [Tim Pope's post regarding good commit messages|http://tbaggery.com/2008/04/19/a-note-about-git-commit-messages.html].

GitHub also shows just the first line... Could you also make it like this for Stash? It would certainly make it less cluttered and would promote *better* practices.

And it doesn't seem hard to implement.
fields.summary: Show only the first line from commit message in "Commits" tab

fields.description:
Given a user, {{user}}, and a test project, {{TEST}} with two repositories:
* Repo {{test1}} - {{user}} is granted {{REPO_READ}} permission
* Repo {{test2}} - public repo

When called by {{user}}, {{RepositoryService.countByProject(TEST)}} would only return 1, not 2.

Users don't technically have a permission on public repositories.  Their ability to read the repo is implied.  Unfortunately, several of the API calls don't handle this implicit permission grant (or AnonymousUsers) very well.
fields.summary: RepositoryService#countByProject does not take into account repositories that are publicly accesible

fields.description:
As requested on https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/266364/how-do-i-avoid-a-duplicate-element-using-the-stash-project-general-decorator

Currently these decorators only allow you to specify content areas.

What is needed is a way to specify items for a left menu, similar in shape to the project settings page.

Possible implementations:
* An additional "navWebSectionKey" which will load web items as nav menu items.
* A second content tag respected by the decorator (this may not be possible) for specifying the nav area content.
fields.summary: Add support for a left nav to the project and repo decorators

fields.description:
Crowd can generate duplicate rows Crowd *for memberships*. This causes exceptions when Stash tries to sync with crowd.

Stash has constraints in {{cwd_membership}}.
{code:java}
org.hibernate.NonUniqueResultException: query did not return a unique result: 2
	at org.hibernate.internal.AbstractQueryImpl.uniqueElement(AbstractQueryImpl.java:914) ~[hibernate-core-4.2.5.Final.jar:4.2.5.Final]
	at org.hibernate.internal.CriteriaImpl.uniqueResult(CriteriaImpl.java:396) ~[hibernate-core-4.2.5.Final.jar:4.2.5.Final]
	at com.atlassian.crowd.dao.membership.MembershipDAOHibernate.findInternalMembership(MembershipDAOHibernate.java:356) ~[crowd-persistence-hibernate4-2.7.1-rc.jar:na]
	at com.atlassian.crowd.dao.membership.MembershipDAOHibernate.isUserDirectMember(MembershipDAOHibernate.java:211) ~[crowd-persistence-hibernate4-2.7.1-rc.jar:na]
	...

{code}
h4. Workaround

Remove and reconnect the affected Crowd directory. More details:
 [https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASHKB/Unable+to+sync+crowd+user+directory+-+query+did+not+return+a+unique+result]
{panel:title=Additional note}
The fix for this issue inserted the {{uk_mem_dir_parent_child}} into a table on our database. After upgrading to versions above that fix, you should get the duplicate records removed from the database and all fixed.

If your database was in bad shape you could still have a few duplicate records that hadn't been deleted during the upgrade task. This will get your synchronisation failing with the following error:
{code:java}
2016-08-25 18:07:57,939 ERROR [Caesium-1-4] o.h.e.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper ERROR: duplicate key value violates unique constraint "uk_mem_dir_parent_child"
2016-08-25 18:07:57,963 ERROR [Caesium-1-4] c.a.c.d.DbCachingDirectoryPoller Error occurred while refreshing the cache for directory [ 2457601 ].
org.hibernate.exception.ConstraintViolationException: could not execute statement

{code}
If you're hitting that, please proceed with the following steps:
 # Create a copy of your External Directory connection (i.e. LDAP, JIRA, etc) in {{Administration >> User Directories}}
 # Delete the old one
 # The issue won't return as the constraint will never allow Crowd's bug manifest again.{panel}
fields.summary: Unique key constraints not working for Embedded Crowd table cwd_membership

fields.description:
Currently a user must have admin access to generate read-only access keys.  Any user with read access or higher should be able to add access keys.

As an example for why this is a problem, I do not have administrator privileges for the JIRA repository on stash.atlassian.com.  Therefore, I can not use an access key to add the repository to FIshEye.

One concern that has been raised is that this would mean that I could generate access keys and give them out to people who should not have access to the repository.  But I could just as easily give them my username and password.  One potential approach to mitigate this is that we could support auditing of which user added an access key, and present a list of access keys when that user is deleted or disabled.
fields.summary: Allowing non-admins to add repository/project access keys in Stash

fields.description:
[Current auto-merge functionality|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Automatic+branch+merging] requires a 'release branch' to achieve automatic merging.

For several projects, we do not need the git flow concept of a 'release branch', as there are no old versions. We would still like to utilize an auto-merge/cascading merge feature.

*Our practice*
Code merged to Master is automatically deployed direct to production via a CI server. Master is protected so only authorized staff can trigger a production release. The CI server also does automated deployment, automated testing yada yada yada.

Code merged to Develop is deployed direct to staging via a CI server.

To allow con-current development of very complex features (4 months of work), we utilize a 'feature branch'.

Feature Branches are branched from 'master', and may also have a CI build against them.  A completed Feature Branch is then merged to develop, and ultimately master.

The problem with this approach is that to keep the feature branch up to date requires manual intervention, as such is sometimes forgotten by developers, resulting in an extended merging duration.

What we want is the ability to configure an auto-merge from master to any un-merged feature branches.

*How this could work with Sash*
Add an option the auto merge configuration screen to enable one or both of the following types of merge.

1.) Release Branch Cascading Merge
As per https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Automatic+branch+merging
2.) Continuous Integration Cascading Merge
This merge will trigger on pull request to Master if in the [stash branching model screen|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Using+branches+in+Stash#UsingbranchesinStash-model] the production, feature, and development branches are enabled. The changes in Master will be merged into any feature branch that is ahead of master.
In the event the merge is not possible (i.e. conflict), a pull request should be created to prompt a developer to manually make the merge.
fields.summary: Allow auto merge to feature branches from master without using release branches

fields.description:
In our flow we use feature branch and task branches for each development subtask. The Jira id is part of the branch names so that:

*TELL-123/Integration*
is the feature branch and then from it we branch for each subtask:
*TELL-123/TELL-567_FirstSubTask*
*TELL-123/TELL-567_SecondSubTask*
...

and each subtask get reviewed separately, first integrated to the feature integration branch and when we can close the user story, Integration ends up to the master.

It would be great to have - in the branch listing page - the branches being grouped like SourceTree does. See attachment of my current SourceTree view.
fields.summary: Group branches in the Branch listing page like in SourceTree

thanks

fields.description:
I am primarily a developer, but I also serve as the Stash administrator. Many of the projects in our company don't concern me on a day-to-day basis.

As the number of projects in our repository grows and grows, I find my Stash "dashboard" to be getting slightly cluttered from the listings. Right now it's not causing a huge problem as we have only about a dozen -- but there's a large mass of projects slated to be imported from our SVN server which will lower the signal-to-noise ratio down to the point where the page will be virtually useless to me.

JIRA seems to have solved this problem reasonably well -- if I am a JIRA Admin, I am still able to administer the project via the administration panel, but when I am outside the "admin" mode, I don't see the extraneous projects for my day-to-day usage.

Bamboo also has a decent solution with its dashboard filter. (And given that you all don't seem too keen on mucking with permission levels, perhaps it's the better solution.)
fields.summary: Provide means to hide projects from listing
